skill.name: api-organization
skill.description: Explains the standardized API organization pattern for this codebase. Use when creating new API endpoints, API clients, or modifying existing API structure. Covers the 5-file system (endpoint-types, endpoints, api-client, admin-api-client, protected-endpoints), role-based access patterns (admin vs regular users), and TypeScript type safety across the API layer. All API code lives in src/lib/api/ following this exact pattern.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with no executable code. Provides architectural guidance for API organization patterns. No network calls, file system access beyond its own files, or code execution capabilities detected.

content.value_statement: API code becomes scattered and inconsistent across a codebase. This skill provides a standardized 5-file pattern for organizing API endpoints, types, and clients with full TypeScript safety and role-based access control.
actual_capabilities: Defines 5-file API structure: endpoint-types, endpoints, api-client, admin-api-client, protected-endpoints
Documents Supabase Auth integration for automatic session handling and token extraction
Explains role-based access patterns for admin vs regular user endpoints
Provides TypeScript type safety from params through responses
Shows environment variable configuration for API base URLs
limitations: Does not include executable code templates - only documentation patterns
Requires manual implementation of the 5-file structure

best_practices: Define all TypeScript types before implementing endpoint functions for type safety
Use getAuthHeaders() in api-client to extract Supabase access token automatically
Call checkAdminPermission() before any admin-only API operations
Keep endpoint URLs in one centralized file for easy maintenance
anti_patterns: Hardcoding URLs instead of using API_ENDPOINTS constants
Skipping type definitions and using 'any' for API responses
Making API calls directly without using the protected-endpoints wrapper
Forgetting to call checkAdminPermission() before admin operations

faq.question: Does this skill work with other auth providers?
faq.answer: Yes. The 5-file pattern is auth-agnostic. Replace getAuthHeaders() to use your auth provider's token extraction.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of endpoints supported?
faq.answer: No hard limit. Each domain in endpoint-types.ts maps to endpoints.ts. Add as many domains as needed.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing API code?
faq.answer: Migrate URLs to endpoints.ts, define types in endpoint-types.ts, replace fetch calls with apiGet/apiPost wrappers.

faq.question: Is my API data stored securely?
faq.answer: The pattern uses Supabase httpOnly cookies and RLS policies. Security depends on proper Supabase configuration.

faq.question: Why is my admin check failing?
faq.answer: Verify the users table has correct role values. Call checkAdminPermission() before admin operations. Check user session exists.

faq.question: How is this different from standard fetch?
faq.answer: This pattern adds type safety, centralized auth, role-based access, and consistent error handling across all API calls.
